abstract.para: Installation of &peloton; should be straightforward on many platforms but there are always occasions when a manual install may be required. This document details installation procedures and the packages, libraries and applications upon which &peloton; depends.

sect2.title: Python libraries
sect2.para: The following pythonlibraries are either required always required when using particular modules and must be installed either by installer scripts (distutils, Debian package etc) or by the system administrator. The summary table (see ) details which packages are necessary under what circumstances.

listitem.para: Twisted Version >=8.0.1 obtainable from .

Twisted 8.0.1 introduces a bug not present in the 2.5 series with regard the re-raising of Failures. If one processes raises an exception which is caught in another that tries to pass it onto yet another deferred, Twisted 8.0.1 raises an exception. The issue is with pb.py in the spread module and can be demonstrated with peloton/patches/test_patch_8_0_1.py. The same patches directory contains pb_r23300.py which is the entirety of pb.py r23300 which resolves this issue (which was raised on Twisted Trac as issue 3174). Please use this file if installing from the 8.0.1 tarball.
ZopeInterface is a requirement of Twisted; if you've installed from the above Twisted tarball you'll need to get the latest Zope interface egg from: .

Client-side libraries for AMQP. There are few choices in this domain at the moment, but the AMQP spec is compelling and has a growing backing of heavy-weight sponsors and good implementations. Pending the development of a Twisted AMQP protocol suite (which is on the todo list for this project) the Apache QPID Python libraries are used. Installation requires a manual step to install the AMQP specification files; curiously the spec that comes with the download is not the correct version. Install as follows:
Download and install the Python QPID library (tar file is .

Now, in the directory to which qpid was installed make a directory called amqp_specs into which you must place the spec file downloaded from
here. Thus if you have .../site-packages/qpid/ you must now also have .../site-packages/amqp_specs, for example.
Genshi is the default templating library used for XML and HTML output and it is a requirement to have it. Obtained from or easy_intallable. Ubuntu also have a python-genshi package.
&peloton; also supports the Django templating library as an option; simply installing Django into your Python path will enable django templates.
PySQLite - the Python library for working with SQLlite which is used by the Backpack storage module.
PyCrypto is the Python cryptography library. Debian/Ubuntu package python-crypto is fine otherwise the package may be downloaded from .
RabbitMQ Version >=1.2.0

RabbitMQ is a supported messaging backend. MQ servers need to be running in the &peloton; environment and these can be downloaded from the RabbitMQ site at . Packages are available for many platforms from the RabbitMQ site including Debian/Ubuntu and Windows - these include or will cause to be installed the Erlang language libraries.

note.para: Debian/Ubuntu users installing RabbitMQ via the .deb packages are strongly advised to start the server using the init.d script initially. Starting manually requires the appropriate user be set as well as other conditions and can cause confusion. Once familiar with RabbitMQ it's easier to negotiate its setup.

listitem.para: Documentation for setting up RabbitMQ can be found on the site: in particular the instructions for clustering must be followed carefully - do not forget to copy the cookie to all hosts; without this hosts will not cluster together. More information about AMQP, its internals and security model can be obtained from the very readable specification located at .

sect2.title: Dependency summary
sect2.para: The following table summarises all the dependencies for &peloton;. The type column indicates what kind of dependency this is: P is a pure python library; PB is a Python built-in library (partly or entirely C code); A is an independent application. Versions indicated are those tested by the authors and do not imply that other versions of given packages will definitely not work.
Where a package is defined as required with a tick in brackets - (&tick;) - it may be substituted with another providing identical functionality.

row.entry: AMQP provider; any other provider conformant to the spec may also be used.

sect1.title: Running behind Apache2
sect1.para: Both mod_proxy and mod_rewrite can be used to re-direct calls into Peloton. mod_rewrite is particularly useful for trapping requests to /static such that they are delivered by Apache itself rather than by Peloton via the proxy (this is faster).

sect2.title: Debian/Ubuntu
sect2.para: Ubuntu and Debian are popular platforms in the linux world and have the relevant Apache modules ready to use. However, the proxy.conf file is configured to Deny from all thus ensuring that error 403 (forbidden) is returned when you start your proxy. Set this to Allow from all to resolve this issue.

sect1.title: The bleedin' edge developer's super-quick start guide
sect1.para: If you're not a bleedin' edge developer looking to hack and explore and risk getting lost, move on and wait for the complete release of this code which will include friendly documentation and more utility scripts to get you up and running with little effort.
If you're still here, the following should get you going just about.

listitem.para: Install all the dependencies listed in this document.
Checkout the trunk to a location we will hence forth refer to as $PELOTON.
If using RabbitMQ, initialise by running the bash script $PYTHON/bin/initrabbitmq which creates some users, vhosts, realms and permissions.
Add the following to your PYTHONPATH:

We will now start one Peloton Service Controler (PSC). Many PSCs form a domain and each PSC will start workers that actually run services. This PSC will use configuration files in the $PELOTON/example/config directory and set a single service path pointing to $PELOTON/example/service which contains the TestService. TestService contains a few methods that demonstrate various points and provides a handy place to put little test code of your own.
Start as follows:

The arguments are self-explanatory except for the flags; the test service we will start in a moment will only start on nodes with the BAMBI flag set (for demonstration purposes). For further arguments run psc.py with the -h argument.
Now the PSC is listening to web-based protocol requests on port 8080, Twisted RPC request on 9100 and SSH console requests on 9110.
Let's start a service. Open a new console and run:

informalexample.programlisting: > ssh -l admin -p 9110 localhost [ password is 'admin' ] >>> start('TestService')

listitem.para: You will see log output scroll up the PSC console and the service will start.

Now in the $PELOTON/example/service/testservice/scripts folder you will find two scripts to test the service (all are noddy and have the hostname to which to connect hard coded at the top of the file).
pecho.py takes one argument which is sent to the echo method on TestService and returned to be displayed.

testpclient.py takes no arguments and makes n calls to the sumint method where n is defined at the head of the code. This can be used to test performance and to demonstrate robustness in the face of failing nodes.

Now let's start another node. This is very alpha pre-release so some more args required to get over things which will become automagical. You may want to start this PSC on another host; if doing so you'll need to make sure the messagingHost is set to the IP address of your messaging host in $PELOTON/example/config/grid.pcfg.
Start the second and subsequent PSCs as follows (the extra flags only required if this is the second PSC on a given host otherwise you may use the same incantation as before):

informalexample.programlisting: > cd $PELOTON/src/peloton > python psc.py -c $PELOTON/example/config -s $PELOTON/example/service \ --nodetach --loglevel=debug --flags=BAMBI --disable=shell # ONLY IF ANOTHER PSC IS RUNNING --anyport # ONLY IF ANOTHER PSC IS RUNNING

listitem.para: Now from the SSH console you can again issue a start('TestService') and you will see the service start on all nodes that have the BAMBI flag set. Experiment with starting some nodes with no BAMBI flag. You can invert the behaviour by changing the service's configuration file (exercise for the reader).
Finally, to create a new service all of your very own you can use the handy newservice.py tool found in $PELOTON/src/tools/. Change to $PELOTON/example/service and run:
A new directory called myservice is made and populated with an empty service. Simply edit myservice.py to get started. You can immediately start the service from the console with start('MyService').

sect1.para: These are extraordinarily brief instructions but hopefuly the very keen will find them useful pending more complete documentation.
